facts.text: Appeal is from the judgment and decree dated April 11, 1962 of the Orissa High Court in First Appeal No. 61 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated April 11, 1962 of the Orissa High Court in First Appeal No. 61 of 1959. V. Viswanatha Sastri and T. V. R. Tatachari, for the, appellant.

facts.text: Orissa High Court reversed the decree of the Court of the Subordinate Judge, Berhampur.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, by special leave, is against the decree of the High Court of Orissa reversing the decree of the Court of the Subordinate Judge, Berhampur and dismissing the plaintiffs suit for recovery of Rs. 8,216

facts.text: Plaintiffs suit for recovery of Rs. 8,216 due on a promissory note executed by Kontaru Naiko, defendant No. 1 for Rs. 6,000 was dismissed by Orissa High Court.

anchor.surface_text: reversing the decree of the Court of the Subordinate Judge, Berhampur and dismissing the plaintiffs suit for recovery of Rs. 8,216 due on a promissory numbere executed by Kontaru Naiko, defendant No. 1 for Rs. 6,000.

facts.text: Plaintiff obtained a registration certificate under s. 5 and r. 5 of the Orissa Money-Lenders Act, 1939 on March 31, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff money-lender obtained a registration certificate under s. 5 4  and r. 5, of the Orissa Money- Lenders Act, 1939  Act III of 1939 , hereinafter called the Act, and the rules thereunder, on March 31, 1952.

facts.text: Plaintiff obtained another registration certificate in 1955 stating maximum capital of Rs. 8,000.

anchor.surface_text: He obtained another registration certificate in 1955 which said that the maximum capital for which the certificate is granted is Rs. 8,000. The plaintiff advanced the loan to defendant No. 1 on May 19, 1954

facts.text: Plaintiff advanced the loan to defendant No. 1 on May 19, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff advanced the loan to defendant No. 1 on May 19, 1954 and sued for the recovery of the amount due on this loan.

facts.text: Defendants contended that the suit was not maintainable as the maximum capital for the 1952 registration certificate was Rs. 2,000.

issues.text: Whether, in the absence of any specific provision in the Act providing for the fixing of the maximum capital which a money-lender can invest in money-lending business, it was open to the State Government to frame a rule in that regard

anchor.surface_text: We hold that in the absence of any specific provision in the Act in this case providing for the fixing of the maximum capital which a money-lender can invest in money-lending business, it was not open to the State Government to frame a rule in that regard and that the rules

issues.text: Whether the rules about mentioning the maximum capital for which the registration certificate was wanted and the mention in the certificate of the amount of the maximum capital lead to the conclusion that the registration of the money-lender will become void if he exceeds the limit of the maximum capital laid down in the registration certificate

anchor.surface_text: the rules framed by it about mentioning, in the application, the maximum capital for which the registration certificate was wanted and the mention in the certificate of the amount of the maximum capital for which the certificate is granted, do not lead to the conclusion that the registration of the money-lender will become void if he exceeds the limit of the maximum capital laid down in the registration certificate.

issues.text: Whether registration certificates of higher denomination obtained during the currency of a registration certificate have retrospective operation

anchor.surface_text: We do not consider it necessary to decide the other point raised with respect to the retrospective operation of the registration certificates of higher denomination obtained during the currency of a registration certificate.

issues.text: Whether the suit for recovery of loan is maintainable by a money-lender who advanced the loan in excess of the maximum capital in his registration certificate

anchor.surface_text: It was contended for the defendant that the suit was not maintainable as the maximum capital for which the plaintiff had obtained the registration certificate in 1952 was Rs. 2,000 and under the provisions of the Act and the rules framed thereunder, he could not have advanced loan in excess of that amount and that his doing so made the registration of the appellant as a money-lender void and therefore the suit for recovery of Rs. 2,000 even was not maintainable.

anchor.surface_text: We hold that in the absence of any specific provision in the Act in this case providing for the fixing of the maximum capital which a money-lender can invest in money-lending business, it was number open to the State Government to frame a rule in that regard and that the rules framed by it about mentioning, in the application, the maximum capital for which the registration certificate was wanted and the mention in the certificate of the amount of the maximum capital for which the certificate is granted, do number lead to the companyclusion that the registration of the money-lender will become void if he exceeds the limit of the maximum capital laid down in the registration certificate.

anchor.surface_text: We hold that in the absence of any specific provision in the Act in this case providing for the fixing of the maximum capital which a money-lender can invest in money-lending business, it was number open to the State Government to frame a rule in that regard and that the rules framed by it about mentioning, in the application, the maximum capital for which the registration certificate was wanted and the mention in the certificate of the amount of the maximum capital for which the certificate is granted, do number lead to the companyclusion that the registration of the money-lender will become void if he exceeds the limit of the maximum capital laid down in the registration certificate.
